dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Then a sound...  Click-clack, click-clack, click-clack... The familiar sound of chalk writing on a blackboard. Fade up to see... A hand zooming across a blackboard at incredible speed, forming an endless algebraic equation. Amazingly, when the writer reaches the end of the blackbo he does not lift the chalk and return to the left side to begin a new line -- instead he simply loops around and continues writing, right to left, upside down. The college students in his class -- all male and dressed late Victorian clothes -- smile at this familiar peculiar and tilt their heads to try and read the endless equation copying furiously into notebooks. The hand continues to zoom along the blackboard... and th slows... and then stops... the students wait... the hand the chalk on the blackboard for a moment and we finally see... ALEXANDER HARTDEGEN, a handsome young man not much older his students, standing at the blackboard. He is gazing ou window, looking at a bird on a tree branch. He smiles. The students glance to one another. Alexander remembers himself and turns back to the blackbo his hand again flying as:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: So -- length, width, breadth -- formulate the area and of course we arrive at solid mass. But imagine if we continue the equation as I've done -- can't we begin to recognize another dimension beyond the first three? I theorize we begin to find duration -- the object's place in time. Let's note that as "D" here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander reaches the left side of the blackboard and loo around again in an unbroken line to continue the equation from left to right again. The students are hopelessly lost. They finally stop copyi and just watch Alexander work, admiring his brilliant innovation. Meanwhile, a man watches from the back of the lecture hal He is DAVID PHILBY, Alexander's closest friend, a bit old

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. If we accept the theoretical possibility of duration as a fourth dimension we find that our equation might -- no, that's not right -- He erases some numbers quickly with his hand, sending up cloud of chalk dust, he coughs.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: -- there, that looks more like it... He continues to scribble at lightning speed. Then... He begins humming to himself. The students watch, amused. Philby smiles. Alexander finally stops humming and writing. Steps back a looks at the equation. Then he turns to his students.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Does this make any sense to you? The students are confused. One offers:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Sir, if I may, wouldn't it be easier if you applied a Fibonacci sequence to the differential coefficient?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (smiles) It's not supposed to be easy, it's supposed to be beautiful... All of you think about that tonight and we'll press on tomorrow. Good afternoon. The students begin to rise, class over. They leave the classroom talking eagerly about Alexander's theories, inspired. A sudden new angle: from above we see Alexander going to Philby, leaving the classroom talking with him. We are in the upper balcony of the classroom. A solitary figure loo down, watching them. This new figure is a thin man with pale skin, dry like parchment. Somehow ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander walks with Philby:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. The point is I know it will work once the, um, numbers and such are in order.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Do you know you were humming?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I was not.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Somewhere around "D+2xy something something."

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Damned if I can keep her out of my equations.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Tonight's the night?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (checking pocket watch) God, and I'm running late -- A PRIM WOMAN appears before them:

dialogues.speaker: PRIM WOMAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Hartdegen, Dr. Philby... Dean Fulton would like to see you. Alexander and Philby exchange a look. Gulp. They follow t prim woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow the prim woman, Dean Fulton's secretary, into dark, paneled office.

dialogues.speaker: PRIM WOMAN
dialogues.text: He's outside. Alexander and Philby move through the office and out to a garden courtyard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oddly, chickens are clucking about the courtyard. The thin man we saw before, DEAN FULTON, is casually toss down feed for the chickens. With his other hand he carrie an umbrella to protect himself from the sun. He does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, watch your step. Alexander and Philby stop. Dean Fulton looks up and smil benevolent.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: My fowl have polluted the yard.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Dean Fulton... Dean Fulton continues to lazily scatter feed for his chickens.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Dr. Philby, Dr. Hartdegen. I received the most extraordinary letter last week. From a parent. We are always pleased to receive letters from parents. They are our employers, after all. This gentleman's son is in your class, Dr. Hartdegen.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (knows what's coming) I see.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: As I recall the syllabus the name of your tutorial is "Applied Mathematics and Engineering", am I correct?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Exactly correct, sir. Dean Fulton stops scattering feed and gazes at Alexander a smile. This is an old game between them and they both rather enjoy it. To a point.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Well, just as I thought. Surely it's all been a terrible mistake. This parent actually suggested that your freshman course in applied mathematics has somehow become a seminar on theoretical physics!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Imagine that.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: But I know that none of my faculty would ever deviate from the assigned curriculum.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well... perhaps I have "deviated" the tiniest bit.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Might I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Because the assigned curriculum is boring. Philby groans very quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Sir, that curriculum is forty years out of date. The students today are looking toward the new century -- they want to be challenged and inspired, not spoon-fed dusty old equations that have been proved a thousand times. They want to explore.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Do they? Dean Fulton smiles and then begins to scatter feed again. Alexander Alexander

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: What are these animals, gentlemen? and Philby exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Um, your chickens, sir. helpfully offers:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: And roosters.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: No, Dr. Hartdegen, they are not just chickens and roosters. They are science. Perhaps they aren't "inspiring" to you. Perhaps they don't "challenge" you --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No, sir --

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Animal husbandry is science, Dr. Hartdegen. I have been breeding these fowl for fourteen years. I have filled a library with information on their feeding patterns, social behavior and  breeding. Empirical, exacting, quantifiable records.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Sir -- Dean Fulton looks up at him, his eyes cold:

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: вЂњDurationвЂќ is not a dimension. Scientists do not imagine the world around them. They do not wool- gather or cloud-spin. They prove. They demonstrate. Columbia University does not teach fantasy. Philby shoots Alexander a warning look, but Alexander can help himself:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: With respect, sir, would we have the telegraph without fantasy? Would we have radium and X-rays without someone first dreaming we could?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: The advances you speak of were the result of countless years of study and empirical experimentation, a careful evolutionary process, not chalkboard parlor-tricks.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My equations are not parlor-tricks!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Abstract mathematics, relativity of dimensions, geometrical "durations" - even allowing for the uses of speculation, what is the point?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Because it's a new way of seeing the world! Of seeing our place in it!

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Sir, if I may --

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: (with finality, to Alexander) Young man, we have a way of doing things here. Radical theorizing is not acceptable. Have I made myself understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Very good. Now if you will excuse us for a moment. Alexander goes back into the office.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: If I might explain, sir --

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: You supported his application, Dr. Philby. You are his senior, advisor. I depend upon you to restrain his... excesses. Any repetition of the behavior I witnessed in his classroom today and there will be consequences for you both.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN FULTON
dialogues.text: Now you are upsetting my fowl. Please go. Philby extricates himself from a chicken pecking at his s and goes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's a dinosaur. He's already extinct, he just doesn't know it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander and Philby are in an open horse-drawn streetcar heading downtown. Everywhere around them, the massive cit bustles. New York City at the end of the 19th Century. It is vibra to the point of frenzy; reaching for the future in a furi upheaval of construction. Title: NEW YORK CITY - MAY 12, 1895 - 5:17 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: .. One day he'll be discovered by some future archeologists and they won't know what to make of him. The thick brow, so lacking in imagination. The dim little eyes, devoid of curiosity.  Alexander identical Alexander

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: You know generally teachers are supposed to teach real equations that add up to real numbers.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Where's the challenge in that?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Alex, this is your first year as an associate professor. You might want to play things a little more conservatively.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You sound like my father... points to the masses of grey businessmen, all in bowler hats, marching along the sidewalk:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Look at them, Philby, all alike, everyone in an identical bowler hat. Do you want your students to turn out like them?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I want my students to emerge with theoretical and practical knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I don't. I want them to run along this street and knock off every bowler they see.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: You may not like it, but this is the world we live in, Alex. Little grey men with little grey hats.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: But shouldn't it be better? Shouldn't we be teaching our students to imagine a world beyond all this? points to a new building going up, a complex spider's web of steel girders.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Look at that, Philby. A steel frame building. Ten years ago it was unheard of. No little grey man thought of that. The new Century belongs to men who are willing to imagine the impossible... Their streetcar passes a few huddled beggars on the curb The businessmen ignore them. Alexander watches them, his eyes sad.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (quietly) In the future, we'll be better.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander's sprawling Victorian house sits on a quiet str There is a quaint shop right across the street. The shop features a window showing a female mannequin dressed in period clothes. The sign above the shop: BRANSON'S APPARE AND HABERDASHERY. Alexander and Philby hurry into his house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander's house is a lovely world of Victorian elegance constantly at war with his erratic and creative enterpris Everywhere Alexander's scientific passions are evident: animal skulls rest alongside leather-bound tomes; mechani inventions in various states of completion rest atop heav mahogany tables; test tubes and microscopes are spread ou an unused piano. The one facet that most immediately reflects Alexander is aural: the ticking of scores of clocks; a steady metronom cadence. Alexander bounds in, Philby following.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: MRS. WATCHIT, Alexander's housekeeper, troops down the stairs. She is a wry and commanding British woman in her 60's.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Oh huzzah, the master's home.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Do you have it?!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Philby.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Watchit. You're looking in the pink.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Must be all the exercise I get scampering up and down these stairs like a wee lamb.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Don't torture me -- do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: I have it, but don't you think for one moment I'll be letting you go out in that filthy coat -- now go upstairs and change. I've laid out your green coat.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What's the matter with -- ? (he notes he is covered in chalk dust) -- What would I do without you, Mrs. Watchit? He bounds up the stairs. Phiby follows.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: And change your tie! She bustles off, grumbling happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles Darwin stares at us. Imposing. Inspiring. Challenging. A bust of Darwin looms over Alexander's bedroom. Alexander, in a new coat, is trying to work a complicated knot in his tie. His eyes study the problem in a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Emma actually likes chalk dust -- says it smells like me.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: How romantic... Philby goes to Alexander, helps him with his tie.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: The most able inventor I know and you can't tie a simple four-in-  hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: That's how I knew we were destined to be together. When I met her parents for the first time I came right from class and I was covered in chalk. They sniffed and snorted, but she just smiled. At that moment -- I just knew. How did you know with Molly?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: She made the best Shepherd's pie I ever tasted.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Do you have a romantic bone in your body?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: (completing the tie) No, I'm all bowler hat, remember? Alexander quickly goes to his old coat and transfers his pocket watch, journal and many loose scraps of paper cove in equations to the new coat as:

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Alex, really... good luck tonight. She's a fine girl, and she's done wonderful things for you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: (smiles) She's gotten into your equations. Alexander stops, looks at him. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I guess she has. He glances at his pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I've got to hurry... He hurries out, Philby following...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander races down the stairs, tucking the watch into h vest. They pass a series of clocks of every size and shape tha down the wall along the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: All these clocks -- how can you constantly be running late?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Perseverance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Watchit waits. Alexander and Philby appear down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Now that's more like it. You look a proper gentlemen for once.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Then if Emma turns me down will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: (dry) Oh, I'm already swooning.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ouch -- all right, wish me luck. He begins to sprint out the door -- Mrs. Watchit stops hi with:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: You might be wanting this? She holds up a velvet ring box. He takes the box.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh -- Thanks. Well... (a wink to Philby) .. Time's a wastin'! With that he is out the door. Mrs. Watchit and Philby stand for a moment, catching thei breath after Alexander's tornado of enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I wonder if that poor girl has any idea what she's in for?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: For our sake, I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The many luxurious horse-drawn carriages glide along Fif Avenue with stately dignity. Rich pedestrians stroll alon the sidewalk. Alexander leaps out of a carriage and begins to stride to an entrance to Central Park. He passes a Flower Seller.

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER SELLER
dialogues.text: Have some flowers, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not tonight, thanks. He continues on toward the entrance to the Park -- stops.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No -- I promised her flowers. He turns around and hurries back toward the Flower Seller But... A sudden mechanical clanking sound makes him stop dead in tracks. The Siren's song... He turns... Pulled over to the curb is a magnificent Stanley Steamer automobile. It is a glorious collection of bronze and cop and steel and wooden dashboard and leather upholstery and groaning steam tank and clanking engine. Alexander stares transfixed. Alexander glances at his watch -- running late -- but he can't resist this new marvel. Flowers forgotten, Alexande steps to the MOTORIST, currently tinkering with the car's engine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It's spectacular...

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Thanks. Old Nell's my girl all right. Al least when she decides to move, stubborn beast.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (walking around the car, admiring) I've only read about them -- and the new internals.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Now that's what I call plain crazy -- internal combustion is just too dangerous, all those little  explosions, never catch on.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: How do you keep the water temperature stable?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: There's a cantilevered gasket on the -- Suddenly -- the car lurches forward dangerously -- Alexan instantly grabs the brake lever and hauls it back -- the screeches to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: God -- could have killed me -- bad girl, Nell! How did you know to do that?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I just love mechanical things.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Well, much obliged -- I'm always forgetting the confounded brake -- say, if you wait until I get her up and running I'll give you a perambulation. Tell you all about her.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (pained) Ahhh... I'm afraid I've got a prior commitment.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORIST
dialogues.text: Next time then. We perambulate here most every night.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You have my word... (he takes a last, longing look at the car) .. She's just a beauty. He sprints off into Central Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon shines in the night sky. Gentle period music from a band, glowing lanterns hanging down and the swaying shapes of dancers. We are at a beautiful pavilion in Central Park. A magical antique setting of ease and grace. White linen suits and straw boaters. Parasols and high-button shoes. A beautiful woman stands with her back to us watching th dancers... she slowly turns... EMMA smiles. Alexander stands, just watching her, bewitched. Then they come together and kiss lightly, as befits 1895 decency.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Got here as soon as I could.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Dance with me...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You know I can't.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Trust me... She takes his hand and they dance. She is a natural dance smooth and gentle. He does his best, following her minute cues with great sensitivity. As they dance:

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You promised me flowers.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You promised me flowers tonight, don't you even remember?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Sorry... I was distracted.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (lightly) Well there's something new.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I need to... um... talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Talk away, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not here... alone. May we?  Please? She leads him from the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Let's walk through the park...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander and Emma walk through the park, arm in arm, enjoying the exquisite night. Flickering gaslights provide a dim illumination on the pa they follow as it winds through the dark foliage.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (looking at constellations) .. Orion's belt, pointing to the earth. You see it over the rocks there? Sailors consider that an omen of good fortune; the hunter watching over them on their travels... Are you listening to me, Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (glancing up) What? Yes -- Orion -- good fortune -- sailors.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: All right, what is it now?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (nervously) Emma, you know I have great... admiration for you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Admiration? My my.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I mean... well... affection.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You're getting warmer. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh dammit, I love you! I can't eat, I can't sleep, I can't think, all I do is moon over you and -- hum, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: (mock seriously) And what do you propose, Professor? Shall we hold a seminar to study the problem? A beat. He takes a huge gulp of air and then commits hims -- he dramatically drops to one knee -- and then in a gre rush of words:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Marry me. I'll do everything I can to make you happy and build a life and have babies and make you proud and be worthy of you and... ah... make you happy, did I say that? She looks down at him, tears of joy coming to her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, Professor... He leaps up and embraces her. A long, joyous embrace. He stops --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Wait, I have something for you. He searches through his many pockets -- coat, vest, pants begins plucking out the loose scraps of paper covered wit equations -- but can't seem to find the jewelry box. She watches him for a moment, amused, loving him all the for his befuddlement.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You know, the moment is rather dying here.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Hold on... I know I have it... He finally finds the velvet jewelry box. Snaps it open. Inside is a lovely moonstone ring. The gem is a pale, translucent blue mirroring the full moon above.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I know it's not a diamond but --

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: A moonstone.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Your birth stone. I thought -- She holds a finger to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought right. He slips the ring on her finger. She holds it up to the moonlight, Then... deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Look, it matches the moon... A low voice from the thick trees next to them. Alexander the trees. pockets.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I just might cry. and Emma turn to see a tall THIN MAN stepping from His hands are buried deep in his overcoat

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: Couldn't help but overhearing. Two fine young people starting out on the road of life. I wish you the very best.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: I hope it's a happy journey for you both -- and much as I hate to do this, moved as I am by your protestations of love, I'll be needing your money now.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sir...?

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: And your jewelry too. I guess we could consider this your first little bump on the road to married bliss.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I don't understand. The Thin Man removes a hand from his pocket. He holds a small revolver.

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: Now don't make a scene... there's no cause for that. Just hand over your wallet, will you? He holds the gun up, lethal, a sudden glint as the barre shines in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: Did you hear me, lad?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: All right, all right -- here -- everything -- Alexander swiftly gives the man his billfold.

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: And the watch. Alexander hands over his pocket watch as the Thin Man eye Emma's ring.

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: And the ring.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so, darling. Maybe he'll buy you a diamond now.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Please, not that -- look -- The Thin Man pulls back the hammer of the revolver. Click

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: Give me the ring.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: No... The Thin Man suddenly lurches forward and grabs Emma's ar trying to wrench the ring violently from her finger -- Alexander instantly springs to her defense -- a struggle The gun fires -- the flash of cruel, phosphorous light momentarily illuminating them all starkly -- Emma recoils to Alexander -- Alexander looks at the Thin disbelieving -- The Thin Man glares at him --

dialogues.speaker: THIN MAN
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?! It's only a ring! The Thin Man races away into the darkness. Alexander holds Emma, she clings to him, blood flowing o his fingers. He snatches her up and carries her -- runnin urgently through some trees to a carriage path beyond -- Carriages filled with young lovers float past.

dialogues.speaker: HELP ME
dialogues.text: An empty carriage finally stops -- Alexander lurches into carriage with Emma --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Alexander holds Emma in the back of a carriage. He urgently screams to the driver:

dialogues.speaker: GET TO COLUMBUS HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: The driver whips his horses and the carriage takes off.

dialogues.speaker: I'M TRYING SIR
dialogues.text: Emma clings to Alexander, her hand clasped tight to his v blood flowing out of her, pooling. Her dying eyes just watching him.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARK --
dialogues.text: And then the carriage slows -- stops -- Alexander stabs h head out the window and sees -- A long line of carriage ahead of them. A traffic jam. Pai of lovers enjoying the beautiful night, gazing up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh God... A distant bell begins to toll. Time inexorably, cruelly moving on.

dialogues.speaker: PLEASE
dialogues.text: The driver whips the horse -- tries to maneuver the carri through the traffic jam -- a jumble of horses -- their ho shies -- can't get through. Emma's hand clutches Alexander's vest, fingers moving  slightly. The bell continues to toll. Time running out. Her lips move noiselessly, her eyes stare up at him, pray for one parting glance. He continues to shout to the driver, fighting time, not looking at her:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (desperate)

dialogues.speaker: CARRIAGE DRIVER
dialogues.text: I'm trying, sir! -- I can't get through! Alexander glances down to Emma. She is dead. Her eyes ope He stares at her. Not wanting to believe. The bell continues to toll. Fade to Black... And then a strange sound in the darkness... The roar of a tiger -- distorted, echoing... Then another sound... Click-clack, click-clack, click-clack... Chalk racing across a blackboard. Title: FOUR YEARS LATER. Fade up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless equation -- Alexander's hand speeds across a blackboard -- manic, ferocious. We pull back to reveal... An enormous blackboard, floor to ceiling, two stories hig filling one wall -- and two other blackboards, filling tw other walls, also covered with equations. A shocking flas of Alexander's fevered mind. He stands with his back to us, perched high on a rolling library ladder, his hand violently scrawling numbers in a frenzied rush. He pulls the ladder along as he works, totally absorbed. Title: AUGUST 7, 1899 - 5:23 p.m. The drapes around the room are drawn tight against any hi of the day outside. Windows sealed. In the flickering gaslight we see a cacophony of scientif equipment and experiments filling every inch of the cham below him, two stories filled with beakers and test tubes microscopes and coils; engineering blueprints and gyrosco and the huge chalkboards crowded with layers upon layers intense calculus and geometry and equations. There is another large part of the lab, jutting off from house. A closed curtain conceals this part of the lab. And all the clocks have stopped. The steady metronomic cadence that was the aural life of Alexander's house is n more. We see a number of clocks around the lab. All have been allowed to run down. A knock at the door -- Alexander ignores it -- another kn He finally turns from the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What?! And we see him -- Alexander is very different now: cadave and intense, a face that looks as if it has not seen the in years. And eyes marked by tragedy. Mrs. Watchit enters. The years of dealing with his heartbreak have taken a toll on her as well.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Sir, Mr. Philby is here.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, he --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Tell him to go away -- Philby pushes past Mrs. Watchit. He wears an overcoat and bowler hat.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I won't go away, Alex. Alexander stares down at Philby. Philby is shocked at the change in his friend.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: All right, Mrs. Watchit. You can go.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
dialogues.text: May I get you some --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: That'll be all. She leaves the lab. Alexander Alexander

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: My God, Alex, what's happened to you? climbs down the ladder as:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I've been working.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I came by the house every day after the funeral. And then every week. Then every other month. Then I stopped coming. Did you even notice?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, David.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: It hurt me, Alex. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Then why are you here? proceeds to obsessively tidy the lab, almost hiding things from Philby. Philby is increasingly disturbed by t behavior, as:

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: It's my Jamie's birthday today. Your godson. He's nine years old. At his party he asked me if Uncle Alex was coming. I told him no. Then he asked me if you didn't like him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: For God's Sake, David --

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: There are some things I need to say to you. You may not like hearing them, but I don't know if I'll ever get another chance --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You care for me. And you're concerned. And I have to start living my life again. I hear it from Mrs. Watchit every day.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: But you won't listen. You won't see me, you won't see anyone. What would you like me to tell Jamie? That Uncle Alex is busy? That Uncle Alex is hiding up there in his laboratory --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Hiding?

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: You know that's what it is. Mrs. Watchit tells me you're here at all hours -- day and night --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (sharply) That's because I'm working. You remember that? You used to care about your work.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I care more about my life. And yours. A difficult beat. Alexander

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Alex... Alex, please stand still and look at me. stops. Looks at Philby.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: (gently) What happened to Emma will never go away. It's part of you now and it always will be. But you have to learn to live with it...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I live with it every minute of every day.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I know that --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You don't know that. You couldn't possibly. If I'd only done this, or that, if I'd arrived ten minutes earlier, or later. If we'd taken a different path or I hadn't fought the man for the ring. You have no idea what it is to relive every moment of that night -- consider every action you made -- and every

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one of them wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Wasn't it?... I have a dream almost every night now. The Lady and the Tiger, you remember that story? In the dream I'm alone in a huge chamber with a thousand doors. Behind every door, save one, is a tiger. I have to make the decision. Which door conceals Emma? And I just stand there. looking at the doors...

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Do you find her? Alexander doesn't answer. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Alex, nothing will ever change what happened, but --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: That's where you're wrong. I will change it. A beat. Philby looks at him. Alexander offers nothing mor continues to scurry around the lab.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: David... I appreciate your concern, I do. But I ask you to have faith in me. Just for a little while longer. I'm working on something now. Something... extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You wouldn't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I would.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what... come by for dinner in a week and I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Why don't you come to our house instead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that --

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: When's the last time you were outside this house -- (notes a disheveled cot in the corner) -- or this room?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (tense) I can't leave when I'm so close.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: There are trains leaving Grand Central every then minutes. A dozen liners leaving the harbor. Get on one of them. Go to Singapore, Scotland, Manchuria, anywhere, just away from here --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: That's absurd -- A tense beat. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: You're dying here. Don't you see that?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You won't say that in a week.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: I pray to God that in a week you're not here.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: All right. I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: In a week... we will never have had this conversation. Philby looks at him, mystified and concerned.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Good night, David.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: Good night, Alex.  Philby turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Still wearing that bowler hat. Philby stops. Turns back.

dialogues.speaker: PHILBY
dialogues.text: It's raining outside. Open the drapes and you might know that. He goes. Alexander stands for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits, drinking a glass of brandy. He is staring the curtain concealing the other part of the lab. We notice that all the chalkboards have been wiped clean. He drains the glass of brandy. Bon voyage. Then he rises and moves to the curtain. He pulls the curt back and reveals... The magnificent creation itself: The Time Machine. We take in this beautiful creation of curving brass and t velvet, elegant lines and a hopeful feeling of Victorian futurism, as Alexander moves to the windows by the machin He slowly pulls back all the drapes on the windows. The T Machine sits in an area of the lab that juts off, like a greenhouse with windows offering a generous view of the w around him: his quiet garden and the small dress shop acr the street. Alexander moves to the Time Machine. He sits, nervously settling in. The brass control panel ahead of him has a simple display showing the year and date -- AUGUST 7, 1899 -- and a cont lever that moves forward and back. A beat. He takes a deep breath and then... reaches for th control lever --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is as it was. Gentle period music from a band, glowin lanterns hanging down and the swaying shapes of dancers. A beautiful woman stands with her back to us watching the  dancers... she slowly turns. Emma smiles. Alexander stands, just watching her, his eyes wide, incredibly moved. We note that Alexander wears the clothe he was wearing when he got into the Time Machine. It is t older Alex, pale and thin. She goes to him and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) Got here as soon as I could.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Dance with me...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You know I can't.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Trust me... She takes his hand and they dance. She is, again, a natur dancer, smooth and gentle. He tries to follow her minute cues but the experience of holding her in his arms again almost too much for him. He is overcome with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Alex, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Holding you... again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Darling.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I need... to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: All right...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not here... alone. Please. She leads him from the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Let's walk through the park...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No... let's walk through the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little mystified) All right... He takes her hand and leads her away from the pavilion -- Then he stops, sees he must lead her through one of a num of tree-lined paths out of the park. The gaping darkness the park is strangely ominous. Behind each door a tiger.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Alex, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Nothing -- let's just get out of the park. He takes her arm and makes his decision -- he pulls her quickly down one of the paths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander pulls Emma toward an exit to the city, going as quickly as he can. His eyes dart nervously into the dark trees around them.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Alex...?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Shhh. Let's just hurry on here. We don't have to talk, all right? She stops, pulling him.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Why do we have to race for heaven's sake?!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (looking around, alert) I want to get into the light, that's all. Please... He pulls her along.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: This running along is all well for you -- you're not wearing a corset. Then a sound stops him -- an unholy echo through the nigh tormenting him from his nightmares -- the roar of a tiger

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, it's just the zoo. He grabs her and pulls more quickly, a little desperate.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Please, Emma, it's just a little further. He hurries her along. They finally reach the exit and eme from Central Park to Fifth Avenue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, looks around, sees lots of pedestrians and carriages and gaslight. Safety. Victory. He breathes deeply and smiles. He offers her his arm.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Oh, now you're all gallant. She shakes her head and then takes his arm. They stroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abit later. Alexander and Emma make their way down this most magnificent of boulevards. He holds her arm tightly, if in fear of losing her again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: You're so pale... I hope you're not coming down with something.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine. I'm... (laughs) .. wonderful. Just walking down the street with you again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: We took a walk three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not like this. Never like this. Emma, I swear to you -- if I've learned one thing, it's that moments like this are rare. And I will thank God for them every moment of every day. She is confused at his strange intensity, but respects hi seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: They are rare... (she glances up at the  constellations above) .. Orion's belt, pointing to the earth --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (smiles) The sailor's omen of good fortune. The hunter watching over him on his travels.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: So it's astronomy now, is it? They are passing by the Stanley Steamer at the curb Alexa saw earlier. The Motorist is still tinkering with the engine.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Heavens, look at that now!

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I've seen it. He continues escorting her along.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Now I know you're ill -- passing up the chance to explore some new gadget.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It's only a machine. She stops. Genuinely concerned now.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Alexander... tell me what's going on. Is something wrong? He looks at her deeply:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No, Emma. Everything is finally right. Tonight we're going to start all over again. And this time... I'm never going to let you go. He kisses her deeply. She is shocked at this public displ of affection, pulling back slightly.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Alex... people are staring.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Let them.  He kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: Let them.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I have something for you... He pats his pockets, feels the jewelry box, smiles. Then notes the Flower Seller he saw before.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (smiles) Wait -- I want to do it right this time -- stay here, don't move... Emma stands, mystified, as he goes to the Flower Seller.

dialogues.speaker: FLOWER SELLER
dialogues.text: Have some flowers, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes, as many as you have! A sudden sound makes him spin back -- A frenzy of movement -- on the curb, the Stanley Steamer suddenly lurches forward -- the brake not set -- the Moto jumps out of the way -- the Steamer slams forward to the street full of horse-drawn carriages -- a horse rears and bolts -- panic, screams -- the horse lurches to the curb toward Emma -- the carriage topples over -- Burying Emma in a violent crash. Alexander races to Emma -- too late. A crowd begins to fo Alexander folds himself over her in wordless torment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits in his lab, glaring at the Time Machine. Tormented. Eyes haunted. Drinking a glass of brandy. Not his first. He glares at the Time Machine, his fury building -- then bolts up -- flings the brandy glass away from him -- it shatters -- strides across the lab -- throws himself into Machine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Time heals all wounds -- then let it! He SLAMS the control lever forward violently -- in fury - high-pitched whine -- building -- the world undulating ar Alexander -- Suddenly all the silent clocks in Alexander's lab begin tick --

dialogues.speaker: TIME TRAVEL
dialogues.text: Alexander's spine immediately arches back -- he screams i pain -- The molecules of his body revolt as they are torn forward through time -- as time tears through him -- his whole bo suffers as he bends and floats and rips through time -- w he turns his head his whole face seems to elongate -- He's going too fast -- he eases back on the control lever the pain receding somewhat -- And the world around him changes -- The sun rises and then sets and then rises; in his garden snails zoom past flowers that bloom and die in an instant apples grow ripe and then fall and decay in his garden; a complicated spider's web grows in a corner of his laborat in seconds -- The sun and moon now shoot through the sky, a strobe-like flashing of day and night, finally settling into a strang perpetual grey light. He begins to control the lever a bit more -- it is sensit to his touch -- soon he can glance around a bit without absolute agony -- and then with no pain at all -- In the window of the dress shop across the street he watc a female mannequin as she is redressed, her clothes morph from style to style, a swirl of styles and outfits. And n buildings spring up across the street as the seasons pass a blur, summer-fall-winter-spring-summer-fall-winter-spri His journey is accompanied by a strange symphony -- sound bending around him; voices, music, period radio news repo industry. Sounds that float and flit through his consciousness, distorted, barely recognizable. And bizarre shapes move through his world as well -- ghos like apparitions -- strange and eerie as they bend and mo through space -- people. He can almost control the appearance of the people as he gently modulates his speed with the control lever -- he s Mrs. Watchit bending through time -- Philby, concerned -- then people he doesn't know, architects with blueprints, pointing -- Then the world directly around him is changing -- his lab changing -- walls being torn down -- His lab is now a GARAGE -- a series of swiftly morphing c denoting the passing time as years spin by on his contro panel display in a dizzying blur: 1905... 1919... 1924... In the distance he sees New York City expanding -- the Chrysler Building (1930) and the Empire State Building (1 shoot up. Then the garage is torn down around him -- another construction going up -- larger -- a RESTAURANT. He modulates the control lever -- controlling the ebb and flow of time -- the patrons of the restaurant huddled aro a radio, a news report, FDR's voice... "December 7... A d that will live in infamy..." He notes a store going up next to the dress shop: a newsp shop -- sees banner headlines as the years sweep past -- D-DAY! -- VE DAY! -- VJ DAY! -- an enormous celebration i the street. The years spin by on his control panel: 1946... 1953... 1957... The strange aural symphony continues as he hears music an news, the music evolving from swing to early rock... The restaurant dissolves around him and a HOUSE grows up he is in a den -- a black-and-white TV on -- Alexander ga -- slowly, slightly... On the TV: JFK's funeral... in the den he sees the shape family nestled together, watching the funeral, weeping... He presses on. The years spin by on his control panel: 1963... 1966... 1969... On the new color TV in the den: news reports of the Apoll 11, Neil Armstrong stepping on the moon... "One small ste for man..." Alexander stares, amazed. The aural and visual symphony continues... rock segueing disco, Vietnam news... He is shocked to see the mannequin in a miniskirt! He see the dress shop becoming a department store and the newspa store becoming a high tech electronics shop -- On a bank of TVs in the electronics shop window he sees N leaving the White House for the last time, August 9, 1974 walking to the helicopter, the ferocious victory "V"... Then Alexander is suddenly outside as the house is demoli -- quickly eroding around him -- he is in a VACANT LOT... He is stunned to see the towers of the World Trade Center looming in the distance -- the rollerskaters with boom bo swirling past with the grace of ballet dancers -- and  something so fantastical that Alexander can only gape... An airplane soaring above. The years zip by on his control panel: 1979... 1985... 1989... More disjointed sounds and images, TV reports and radio n and music: oil crisis, plop-plop-fizz-fizz-oh-what-a-reli it-is, Ronald Reagan, punk rock, Gulf War, Clinton... Then order from the chaos -- the overgrown vacant lot is landscaped -- becoming a beautiful PARK... He slows a bit, almost stopping -- intrigued by a transformation across the street: the banks of TV screens replaced by an informational kiosk of some kind. The control panel display clicks more slowly... February 2005... April 2005... May 2005... Alexander continues to stare at the information kiosk as comes to a stop, briefly, at: MAY 24, 2005

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits unnoticed in the Time Machine as he watche group of schoolchildren and their teacher gathering aroun the informational kiosk. It is a public information booth with a video screen showing the word VOX. A glowing red b within the "o". The Vox kiosk is activated when the TEACHER steps in fron a sensor eye.

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Yes, please... tell us about the terraforming. The children watch, delighted, as images of the moon and renderings and videos of some massive engineering project appear on the Vox screen.

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The joint United Nations/Microsoft terraforming operation began nine months ago with the Moon Base Alpha landings. After establishing Plymouth Center the terraformers began colony construction. Can I tell you more?

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: What are they doing now? Alexander watches, stunned. A machine that converses wit people.

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Currently, the terraformers are preparing the first excavation demolitions for the subterranean chambers. It is projected that the first lunar colonists should be landing within the decade. Can I tell you more? Alexander gapes at the Vox kiosk. Magnificent renderings a vast underground metropolis. People living on the moon. He must see this grand adventure out. He presses on...

dialogues.speaker: TIME TRAVEL
dialogues.text: But almost immediately the Time Machine is lurching and buffeting -- a strange darkness spreading over it as air sirens scream -- Alexander is alarmed -- he begins to pull back on the con lever -- the date on the display clicks to: AUGUST 26, 20 And Alexander and the Time Machine suddenly topple over a the ground lurches below them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander looks up from the grass... Right into the eyes of a small albino alligator. The alligator blinks at him and then slithers off, a broo other alligators with it. Alexander glances to the street -- sees an enormous pack rats emerging from a sewer drain -- a thick, undulating carpet of rats -- And Alexander feels the vibrations. The earth, a steady rumble. His eye is drawn to a small puddle of water near him. The water swirls around strangely and then -- whoosh forms into a vortex and spirals away into the sky -- Alexander follows the water with his eyes and finally see it... The Moon. Filling the sky as if it were falling toward the Earth. Parts of the moon are beginning to sheer off -- violently peeling away like the skin of an onion -- as it impacts t gravitational Roche Limit, 7,300 miles above the Earth. moon is currently 230,000 miles above the Earth.) The people on the street race around, tense and desperate flowing along the streets and sidewalks. National Guard soldiers are trying to retain order, urgent voices into megaphones -- Alexander hauls himself up -- and races into the mob --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a man --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What's going on -- ?! The Man pulls away from him, terrified -- Alexander is bustled along the sidewalk in the mass of people -- He tu to a woman:

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Please tell me -- what's happening?! She ignores him -- he is buffeted along in the mob of peo -- then, a voice, remarkably calm in the chaos, a familia voice:

dialogues.speaker: CALM VOICE
dialogues.text: May I help you?... May I help you?... May I help you?... Alexander pushes his way through the frenzy of people tow the voice. Finds himself at... The front steps of the Fifth Avenue New York Public Libra The twin stone lions looming over the chaos on the street The calm voice is coming from another Vox kiosk, an upgra of the one he saw previously. Alexander unintentionally activates the unit by stepping in front of a red sensor e

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I -- what are you?!

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am the Fifth Avenue Public Library informational kiosk. VOX registration NY-114. May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What's happening to the moon?! Informational videos appear on the screen, showing the c and horror of the moon's fall, as:

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The 2005 terraforming demolitions for the lunar excavations sent the moon into a diminishing retrograde orbit resulting in global gravitational fluctuations, increased seismic activity and tidal anomalies. Can I tell you more?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No -- wait -- the moon's falling out of orbit -- that's not possible!

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, considering it is, in fact, happening, I would assume it's possible. The retrograde orbit began in 2005 when the demolitions for the lunar colonies --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Why is it -- breaking up?

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was getting to that... The moon has reached the gravitational Roche Limit, 7,300 miles above the surface of the Earth. This has created pressure on the lunar stratum beyond gravitational tolerances. It might be helpful to know that the nearest public evacuation shelters can be found at Grand Central Station, Madison Square Garden -- Then -- behind Alexander -- the entire street EXPLODES up the asphalt twisting crazily -- people tossed through the air -- And Hell has come to earth. The earth begins to shake and quake and undulate violentl as if gravity itself is rebelling. Above -- a huge part of the moon breaks away -- Alexander gapes around -- horrified to see violent seismi and gravitational upheavals -- the tectonic plates shifti wildly, jutting up at harsh angles -- the East River swir into a twisting cyclone of water spiraling into the sky - And most shocking of all: a volcanic mountain BURSTING u through Manhattan. A National Guard soldier races to him --

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Underground -- we have to -- ! His words are drowned out by a DEAFENING BLAST -- the reverberation sending SHOCK WAVES down the street -- peop are thrown through the air, blood streaming from some punctured eardrums -- In the distance, the volcano is ERUPTING -- The soldier hustles a mass of people toward a subway entr -- they scurry down -- Alexander spins around and races back, towards the Time Machine. As the Vox Kiosk continues its lonely chore:

dialogues.speaker: VOX KIOSK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: May I help you?... May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sprints down the street, passing horrific flash of the end: -- Looters, lighting fires and taking nihilistic joy in t useless treasures... -- A family, kneeling in prayer, holding hands... -- Doomsday cultists, celebrating the end. A macabre Danc of Death as the city dies... -- A man standing quite calmly, trying to use his cell phone... -- A taxi trying to drive through the mayhem, desperate people attacking the taxi, trying to get in, trying to ge away... Then -- the earth HEAVES violently and Alexander is throw the ground -- in the distance, but much closer, another VOLCANO BLASTS UP -- THRUSTING through the earth -- RIPPI aside the Empire State Building and most of midtown Manhattan -- Alexander barely has time to pull himself to his feet bef it happens again -- The THUNDEROUS explosion -- the cascading SHOCK WAVE --  Alexander is hurled through the air -- He SMASHES into a parked car, shattering the windshield - rolls off the car, his coat shredded, a gaping wound in h side -- As the new, closer volcano ERUPTS in a torrent of spewing lava -- great rivers and explosions of lava everywhere -- JETS of lava SHOOT through the air -- incinerating everyt in sight -- Gasping through his pain, Alexander rises and hurries dow the street -- he tosses off his shredded coat -- his inju slows him, but he goes as quickly as he can -- But a vast TIDAL WAVE OF LAVA is careening after him -- burning everything -- And then he see it... the park... the Time Machine. It is a race against time as Alexander sprints for the Ti Machine -- the lava closer and closer -- Alexander leaps to the Time Machine and hauls it to its upright position -- the lava is almost on him -- he dives into the Time Machine and SLAMS the lever forward -- A high-pitched whine -- building -- the world undulating around Alexander -- JUST as the tidal wave of lava ROARS over him --

dialogues.speaker: TIME TRAVEL
dialogues.text: Alexander lurches back in agony -- quickly slows the Time Machine's momentum -- he pants for breath as the red, mol lava glows and then quickly cools into -- Darkness. The eerie blue glow from the Time Machine's control panel the only light. Alexander is now inside a mountain, the perfect sphere of time-energy around the Machine his only salvation. He pushes the lever forward more -- the years spin by on control panel in a blur -- he grits his teeth in pain -- rapid bending through time assaulting him -- Time passes... Alexander is having real trouble breathing now -- The years continue to spin past on his control panel in a dizzying blur.  Time passes... Alexander is in agony -- his body writhes from the assaul time -- every movement is torture -- his skin vibrates an stretches bizarrely -- and he is almost out of air, panti for breath -- He takes one last deep gasp of air -- And holds the breath -- the seconds tick away -- the year shoot past on his control panel, truly a race against tim He's not going to make it -- he can't hold his breath a second longer -- Suddenly -- a flash of blinding sunlight -- The mountain around the Time Machine begins to erode -- quickly wearing away -- Alexander immediately pulls back on the control lever -- reducing his momentum and the assault on his body -- he t a deep, gasping breath -- The date on the display quickly clicks forward and finall stops at: JULY 12, 802,701. Alexander looks at the date, stunned, gasps for breath, fainting... Fade to black...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visions as Alexander fades in and out of consciousness. -- Night. Candles... -- Night. Emma's face... close, concerned... a beautiful angel welcoming him to death... No, not Emma... Another woman. -- Day. Hands, dressing the wound on his side. Tender... -- Day. A room. In a pleasant, rustic house... -- Night. The woman again. Not Emma. But close, concerned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander awakes. Looks around. A simple room in a simple house. He sees his wound has been dressed and cared for. He slowly rises and pulls on his shirt and vest. Goes to door of the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander emerges from the house... And finds himself in a village built around a large centr square. All the buildings are unadorned and designed with architectural simplicity. It has an agrarian and peaceful feeling. And it is totally deserted. The entire village is enclosed by a great, wooden wall. Large gates open to the world beyond. Everywhere beyond t barricade is lovely mountainous and forest scenery. Alexander wanders to the square.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Hello...? Nothing. His word echoes around the eerily empty village. He notes that several tables are waiting in the square. S for dinner. Plates and cups and utensils. No food.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Is anyone here...? Again. Nothing. He goes to the open gates and steps out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A path leads away from the village, cutting through a magnificent forest with lush foliage. He begins to follow the path -- then stops when a curious squirrel scampers onto the path. The squirrel looks at hi large eyes, tilting inquisitive head. Alexander smiles at seeing something so familiar in this strange time.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Hello... The startled squirrel turns and scampers away -- and Alexander is shocked to see a flash of vermillion scales its back. Not a squirrel at all. Alexander continues on for a bit. Most of the lush vegetation is alien to him: enormous fruit hanging on colorful vines; gentle petals and dandelion-like wisps th float on the breezes. It is an untamed wilderness explodi with verdant beauty.  And then he hears something... Voices. He stops, alert. Then he sees figures, heading up the path towards him. And Alexander sees the ELOI. About two hundred of them ar trooping up the path. They are completely human-looking. Very healthy. Simple clothing, not unlike what Alexander wearing. And not one is over the age of 30. Alexander braces himself, not sure what to expect. The Eloi see him... And go to him enthusiastically. Alexander instinctively steps back. No need. The beautifu woman who was tending his wounds, MARA, is first to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: You're up! You must be feeling better --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes... More Eloi crowd around him, all very friendly. A slightly older Eloi, late 20's, KORUS, steps to him. KORUS. And hungry, I'd say. You had such a long journey.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I did... KORUS. Well, we're happy you're here. Come inside.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: We want to hear all about it. Korus and Mara lead Alexander back toward the village. KALEN, Mara's nine-year-old son, grabs Alexander's hand. Alexander is surprised. The Eloi are seemingly a bit more tactile than we are.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: How did you get hurt?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Kalen...

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: (eagerly) I found you. I saved your life. You were bleeding all over the place!

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: That's quite enough, Kalen. Korus claps an arm around Alexander's shoulders enthusiastically, Alexander rocks from the hearty embrace

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: Let the poor man eat first, then he can tell us the whole story! He leads the befuddled Alexander back toward the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gates to the village are now securely locked, a heavy crossbar in place. Alexander and the Eloi are eating dinner, the tables now of fruits and vegetables. Braziers burn around the centra square. Everyone strains to see and hear Alexander. Mara watches him particularly closely from across the tab her cautious eyes never leaving him.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: "Eloi"? KORUS. What are your people called?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you'd call us... New Yorkers. KORUS. (savoring the words) New Yorkers.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: How long did you travel?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Well it seems like a long time -- but it wasn't really. It's rather hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: It must have been hard, leaving your work.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: The journey is part of my work.  KORUS. You can work with us as soon as you're feeling better... Looks like a climber to me. The Eloi agree. Definitely a "climber."

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: We had another visitor from beyond the valley about four years ago. His name was Moren. Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No... KORUS. He said he traveled for two months.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I took a different route.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: What did you do at night?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: (a bit quickly) What's it like where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Oh, very different. But not entirely... I mean we have lots of, um, trees and such. But not everywhere. And more roads. And buildings.

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: To live in. There's a lot of us... beyond the valley. KORUS. New Yorkers.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes. I hope you won't take this the wrong way but is there someone older I could talk to? An elder or patriarch of some kind? The Eloi look at him a little oddly. KORUS. I am the oldest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean someone considerably older. Your father perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: My father has gone to a better place.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to...

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: Of course. You're just tired. Mara, will you look after Alexander tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: (stands, toasting) Friends, join me in welcoming our brother from beyond the valley, Alexander. The Eloi stand and toast. Applause and good fellowship. Before Alexander can open his mouth to respond the Eloi a clearing the table. A bit abruptly. Mara and Kalen go to Alexander, they head back to their house.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: Now how did you get hurt?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I had an accident.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: I figured that. What kind of accident?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Kalen, don't be morbid. Kalen grabs Alexander's hand and pulls him along.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: What do you do on the towers?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: On the towers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm training to be a high climber.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: We'll see about that.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: Iam. Are you a climber?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Ah... no.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you're a mud carrier.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: 'rraid so. Just a regular old... mud carrier. Kalen is disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: That's all right, Kalen... (a wry glance to Alexander) .. Mud carriers are important too. They continue on toward their house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits with Kalen and Mara. The boys's eyes alive with wonder.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Thousands and thousands of people. And sometimes we live in great buildings that reach up five or ten stories.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: And everyone looks like us?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Exactly like you. Well, maybe not as healthy.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Is there a lot of illness?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Some. But I mean we aren't all so... handsome.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: I want to see your home. Will you take me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kalen, right now you need to go up to bed. You're exhausting Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: You'll tell me more tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I will. Good night. Kalen kisses his mother and then kisses Alexander. He goe up the stairs, disappearing to another part of the house.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: His curiosity is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Mm. A beat. Mara gazing at Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Come to the roof. We can talk there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander and Mara emerge from a stairway to the flat roo the house. Alexander stops, looking up... The moon -- or what's left of the moon -- shines in the night. Oddly shaped shards are spread out in uneven intervals. It is bizarrely beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My God... Mara notes his reaction as she sits at the edge of the ro by a large brazier. She lights a fire in the brazier as:

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Sit with me. He goes to her and sits. He notices that other Eloi are also sitting on their roof all around the village, braziers burning like campfires through the night.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Kalen will tire you out if you let him. He's always been curious. His father was firm with him but...  it's just his way.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Your husband is dead?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: He's gone to a better place. He looks over the peaceful night.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: It's hard for me to imagine a better place. Where I come from there's so much... frenzy. Day and night. It seems we're all running faster and faster... (he smiles) .. All in identical bowler hats.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: You're not from beyond the valley.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: What makes you say that? She reaches into her clothing and pulls out his pocket wa She holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: We don't have anything like this. Or the machine where Kalen found you. And I doubt they do beyond the valley... Now where do you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You might find the truth rather hard to understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: (dry) Then you can speak slowly. He smiles. Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: All right... I'm from here. Around here anyway. The machine where you found me allowed me to travel through time... I'm from the past. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Oh, that explains everything.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I know it's hard to believe, but it's true.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: That machine --

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Allowed me to travel from my time to yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: More than 800,000 years. She looks at him. She looks at his pocket watch. Then bac at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Why would you do that? Alexander doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: I might find the truth rather hard to understand?... Can you go back?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes. Or forward into the future. I suppose I really should check on the machine, see that it hasn't been damaged...

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: I'll take you tomorrow... You must have seen a lot on your journey.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: For a time it was astounding. I saw the years spinning by, I was in the years spinning by. We made such advances. I don't understand half of them. There was a machine that talked to me and others that flew through the sky... We must have been incredible thinkers and artists -- A sudden scream cuts through the night -- Kalen -- Mara b up, races down into the house, Alexander following --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kalen is sitting up in bed, eyes wide, screaming -- Mara to him, holds him closely -- Alexander stands in the door

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Kalen, it's all right, I'm here --

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: (terror) They're here! They're inside the house -- !

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: No, you're safe --

dialogues.speaker: KALEN
dialogues.text: They're inside --

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: (calming) Kalen, look at me. There's no one here but us. You see I'm here, you're here, Alexander's here. There are no Morlocks. It was just a dream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds him closely, he is weeping uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: You're safe... Alexander moves away, allowing them their privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits, looking over the night. He notes that mos of the Eloi have gone in, but, oddly, their fires still b on the rooftops. He glances up at the stars, gazing at the dazzling mosaic beautiful lights.

dialogues.speaker: MARA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's asleep. Alexander turns. Mara is standing at the entrance to the roof.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Just a dream. You should sleep too. You're still not well.  A beat. A beat. A beat. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: I'm going to sit with Kalen. Keep the fire burning if you can.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I will... She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: I'll take you to your machine tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Thank you... She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: You seem fascinated by the stars.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You can see so many here.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: (smiles) Don't then have stars where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Not like this... They don't seem so bright with all the city lights. I never really noticed them much... He is on the verge of asking her to join him in enjoying the night.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Good night, then. She turns to go... She stops.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Mara... what's a "Morlock"?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: A child's nightmare, that's all. She goes into the house. He sits for a moment, looking over the beautiful night. glances up at the shards of the moon. O Brave New World...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are moving through the Eloi world. Through lush jungle and glades and forests. Everywhere around us there are fascinating geological and botanical wonders to behold... Bucolic and beautiful. Idyllic... And then the landscape is more mountainous, rocks and the beginning of a splendid desert... the sun is setting... t desert sand burns red in the sunset... still beautiful... And then a shape appears in the distance -- we sweep towa it -- it is hulking -- predatory -- terrifying -- sparkli red as if the setting sun is reflecting from shinning metal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Alexander bolts awake. Unsettled by the dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander and Mara are making their way up an ascending p through the forest with the rest of the Eloi. Kalen is ah of them with some other children. Korus comes to them:

dialogues.speaker: KORUS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Alexander. Feeling up to some work?

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: I'm going to take him to where Kalen found him first. KORUS. And then you'll join us?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Yes. KORUS. Good. We'll see you later then. He moves ahead, walking briskly. Excited about a day of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mara, I had a strange dream last night. I was here, walking through a forest very much like this, and then...

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Then you came to a desert and mountains...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: And you saw a shape ahead of you...

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: We all have that dream.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: All of you?

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: Every night.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: You share dreams? That's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: MARA
dialogues.text: We share everything. He slows, looking ahead, amazed. In the distance, just over the crest of the hill he sees strange point, like the top of a high steeple, jutting up the sky. They approach the crest of the hill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
